P2 protects well with a #4, and there is a fixed #5 on P2 as of 4/13. On P3, after the crux, you can shimmy back into the chimney once it widens to a great rest ledge inside the chimney. Look towards the back and there is an angling crack (angling up towards the top of the chimney where you exit) that takes finger-sized gear so you don't have to run it out after the bolts. P4's mild face... more P2 protects well with a #4, and there is a fixed #5 on P2 as of 4/13. On P3, after the crux, you can shimmy back into the chimney once it widens to a great rest ledge inside the chimney. Look towards the back and there is an angling crack (angling up towards the top of the chimney where you exit) that takes finger-sized gear so you don't have to run it out after the bolts. P4's mild face climbing is so enjoyable after grunting and heaving your way up the last few pitches! I feel the overall crux of this climb is when you inevitably discover that your body is oriented in the squeeze the wrong way and you have to find a way to make a 90 degree reposition - pretty sure I had to do this on every single pitch... Descent: If it's a busy day, see if you can partner up with another party so you're not hauling an extra rope. Got down the North Face rappel in two 70m double rope rappels. Apr 19, 2018

The Kor-Ingalls isn't an incredibly hard route, but it is an incredibly bad route. 5.9+, probably R, one star. There's a decent chance you're dumb enough to go up it anyway, so here's what you should expect: Pitch 1: Low quality, uninspiring scrambling up and through a squeeze chimney. Inexplicably chossy. This pitch has potential to have the absolute best climbing on the entire route if... more The Kor-Ingalls isn't an incredibly hard route, but it is an incredibly bad route. 5.9+, probably R, one star. There's a decent chance you're dumb enough to go up it anyway, so here's what you should expect: Pitch 1: Low quality, uninspiring scrambling up and through a squeeze chimney. Inexplicably chossy. This pitch has potential to have the absolute best climbing on the entire route if you start at a short hand crack below the main ledge most people seem to start at. At this point, your best bet for a quality day is to climb this hand crack and then go climb the North Chimney (or walk back to your car). Pitch 2: Cryptic wide climbing wandering up through more uninspiring, chossy terrain. Maybe hard to protect, but that's less bothersome than the fact that it's a bad pitch that you shouldn't waste time climbing. Pitch 3: Squeeze chimney. Slick calcite, more uninspired and cryptic nonsense; hope you didn't bring a day pack or a thick waistline. There are bolts through the crux, and then you'll fiddle with gear in the back of the chimney so you can feel a little better running out the last 30 feet to the anchors. Not horribly hard, not horribly scary, but just...not good. Maybe two stars. Maybe. Pitch 4: Head up to a chimney and either run it out up more thrutchy squeeze or run it out up the face on the right. Again, not hard and not awfully scary (well, don't fall, or you'll hit the ledge and get hurt), but really uninspiring and forgettable. The Kor-Ingalls isn't bad because it's runout, or bad because it's hard, or bad because it's a series of squeeze chimneys and nonsense; it's bad because it's just a run-of-the-mill bad route. Here is the full list of reasons you should consider it: - It follows an obvious line up the tower - It has some history - You like squeeze chimneys and would like to climb a low-quality one so you appreciate the high-quality ones more It might be 5.10, it might be R/X, whatever, argue that until the cows come home. But it's bad. May 6, 2018

There is so much helpful information on this forum, but I found a lack of approach information. Hopefully you know how to take the road out to Castleton Valley (out UT 198). Take this road for 15.2 Miles, then turn right onto Castlevalley road. Follow this road for 4.7 Miles, then take a sharp left onto a small bumpy dirt road to a parking lot. Take the trail directly out of the parking lot... more There is so much helpful information on this forum, but I found a lack of approach information. Hopefully you know how to take the road out to Castleton Valley (out UT 198). Take this road for 15.2 Miles, then turn right onto Castlevalley road. Follow this road for 4.7 Miles, then take a sharp left onto a small bumpy dirt road to a parking lot. Take the trail directly out of the parking lot into a small slot canyon. After the canyon, you will find a road that goes horizontally across the trail. Take this road LEFT down a short hill.  At the bottom of the hill, take a right by a sign with an arrow and a cairn. Follow this obvious trail all the way to the tower. This approach takes about an hour or slightly more. The climb was great. All of the difficulties were directly on with what was listed. 2nd pitch was more sustained and ended up being a little more difficult than the 3rd pitch, however the 3rd pitch had an interesting crux. 4th pitch was so fun and had some puckering exposure. A #5 Cam would come in handy a few times, and we used a few smaller tricams, one nut passive placement, and the rest of the placements consisted mainly of .4,.75,1,2,3,4 camalots. We rapped off the same route with a single rope 3 times, than with a double rope the last time. DO NOT RAPPEL ABOVE THE FIRST ROUTE ON THE LAST RAPPEL. Rappel over the left face of the pitch (facing outward toward the parking area). All the anchors are bomber. Have a great time climbing this beast. Bring a ton of water, and run a tag line for packs if you bring them, otherwise you will get stuck in the chimney. Also, watch out for multiple widow-maker blocks marked with a white x up and down the route. Jun 14, 2018

You can rap the north face with one 70 meter rope. I've done it. Do a short first rap and swing over to the climbers left and find a couple big rap bolts. It's the belay of this 5.12 sport pitch on the top of the North Face. Those will get you down to the next set of chains and allow for two more clean raps all the way down. Your ends won't be on the ground, but with rope stretch it works out... more You can rap the north face with one 70 meter rope. I've done it. Do a short first rap and swing over to the climbers left and find a couple big rap bolts. It's the belay of this 5.12 sport pitch on the top of the North Face. Those will get you down to the next set of chains and allow for two more clean raps all the way down. Your ends won't be on the ground, but with rope stretch it works out perfectly. Aug 13, 2018

+1 for Garrett's comment above - linking P1 & 2 is a great way to speed up the ascent (fewer belays and transition time). Linking P3 & P4 would also not be bad. We didn't try to conserve gear, and we were fine using the recommended tips-4" single rack since each pitch tends to use different gear. Upper half of P2 had some fixed gear and P3 had bolts (w/o other realistic options for gear other... more +1 for Garrett's comment above - linking P1 & 2 is a great way to speed up the ascent (fewer belays and transition time). Linking P3 & P4 would also not be bad. We didn't try to conserve gear, and we were fine using the recommended tips-4" single rack since each pitch tends to use different gear. Upper half of P2 had some fixed gear and P3 had bolts (w/o other realistic options for gear other than small cracks, deep in the chimney and a little far from the better holds, as mentioned above) so a handful of draws were very useful. P2 it's less tricky, probably tougher if you're not as used to jamming. P3 is a bit more delicate as you're chimney (and then face) climbing on calcite. Keep in mind that this is a "classic" desert sandbag 5.9+. It's probably around 5.10a/b, when I compare to other routes I've done on Castleton. Nov 11, 2018

I closed out the 2018 year with a December 30th summit! Pretty straight forward chimney climb, absolutely beautiful. RAPPEL!! From the north side (giant 3-anchor rap chains), you need MORE THAN 70M. I had to stretch (I weigh 210lbs) and extend with runners before I could barely reach the chains. Either bring another rope, or do a single rope rappel will a tether. Don't rappel Kors, there... more I closed out the 2018 year with a December 30th summit! Pretty straight forward chimney climb, absolutely beautiful. RAPPEL!! Either bring another rope, or do a single rope rappel will a tether. Don't rappel Kors, there will be loads of rope getting caught on blocks and cracks. Jan 2, 2019
Fun route up a great feature. I highly recommend either a .2 or a #5 for the 4th pitch. Protected it with a few not great #4s and some suspect nuts Mar 29, 2019

Awesome route with lots of wide offwidth sections and narrow chimneys. I personally found a single rack from a 0.2 X4 to a #5 Camalot to be sufficient (brought doubles and they ended up being dead weight). I did happen to use the #5 on every pitch, the #4 was too tipped for comfort in some sections. A #6 could be useful but might be more of a nuisance in some areas due to it's bulk. If you're rapping the North Face with a single 70m rope, Jack's comment (8 up) describes it pretty well. The only thing I'd clarify is that the first anchor you rap to (about 40 feet down and left from the triple chains at the top of the North face) is just hangers. There are no rings or chains, just two burly hangers about 6" apart that are rounded on the inside which facilitates smoothly... more If you're rapping the North Face with a single 70m rope, Jack's comment (8 up) describes it pretty well. The only thing I'd clarify is that the first anchor you rap to (about 40 feet down and left from the triple chains at the top of the North face) is just hangers. There are no rings or chains, just two burly hangers about 6" apart that are rounded on the inside which facilitates smoothly pulling your rope. Not sure if they were designed that way or just made that way from many ropes being pulled through. I believe this is the penultimate anchor on Sacred Ground. If you stop by this first anchor, rappels 2 and 3 are a little less than 35m, and the final fourth rappel is pretty much exactly 35m. With rope stretch it's super smooth. Nicolas's comment (6 up) sounds like he missed the first anchor and went straight for the chains directly below the anchor at the top of the North face. You can't make that one with a 70m without first stopping at the Sacred Ground hangers. Awesome climb too! Oct 26, 2020

Party of 3 on a Sunday and somehow we got through it with no one in front or on our tail. Gear: Single .1-.3; Doubles of .4-4 (Highly recommend two 4's for Pitch 2, I think I did the Black Sun Pitch bc the crack was more constant and there is an old bolt in there).   and a #5 will get you through it.  Save a .3, .4 and .5 for after you clip the last modern bolt and you are back inside the... more Party of 3 on a Sunday and somehow we got through it with no one in front or on our tail. Gear: Single .1-.3; Doubles of .4-4 (Highly recommend two 4's for Pitch 2, I think I did the Black Sun Pitch bc the crack was more constant and there is an old bolt in there).   and a #5 will get you through it.  Save a .3, .4 and .5 for after you clip the last modern bolt and you are back inside the chimney on Pitch 3. When I first got back into the chimney on Pitch 3 I thought that there wasn't any protection but some some chalk on a crack on the back wall deep inside showed me the way. Rap the other side and make the walk back around to your bags. Bring a headlamp! Oct 21, 2021
Links naturally as two pitches, with a single's from small to #5 and a 70m. Nov 24, 2021

Got our rope stuck on the pull rapping from the top of P3 TWICE. Had to climb the crux pitch 3 times total yesterday, the rope got stuck both times on chockstones in the chimney and absolutely welded in. Cannot stress how much I did not want to go back up a 3rd time, be better than I was Mar 4, 2022

This is a famous/historical route that attracts climbers of all different skill levels, leading to gear recommendations that are all over the place. Here is a reasonable rack for a 5.10 trad climber: Singles 0.2-4 + nuts, optional doubles in 4 if you don't want to walk it on P2. We brought a 5 and never used it. Don't use the 2,3, or 4 for the gear anchor atop P1. We placed an average of ~5... more This is a famous/historical route that attracts climbers of all different skill levels, leading to gear recommendations that are all over the place. Here is a reasonable rack for a 5.10 trad climber: Singles 0.2-4 + nuts, optional doubles in 4 if you don't want to walk it on P2. We brought a 5 and never used it. Don't use the 2,3, or 4 for the gear anchor atop P1. We placed an average of ~5 pieces per pitch because the climb is so broken up, and the crux pitch currently has 2 slung chockstones and 3 bolts. This climb is much lower quality/less sustained than the North Chimney but still a good time, feels more "adventurey". Sep 27, 2022
Fab route to an amazing summit, and definitely not a giveaway! TR and some photos here: rockaroundtheworld.co.uk/20… Nov 14, 2022

It started snowing when I lead P3 and we didn't have aliens back in the way back machine days. Seems like I ran out the pitch to the belay, I was pretty freaked but down climbing didn't seem like an option. Climbing a calcite chimney with it snowing is something I would not want to repeat. We touched the summit, signed in and bailed before it got any worse. Jan 19, 2023

Awesome route that was my first desert tower. We did the approach in the dark (1 hour) and arrived just before sunrise with no one else around. The first pitch squeeze chimney felt more like 5.8 to me, though the overall characteristic of this route was like old school Yosemite climbing so some OW/squeeze technique will be helpful. A #4 for the second pitch was definitely helpful for the wide... more Awesome route that was my first desert tower. We did the approach in the dark (1 hour) and arrived just before sunrise with no one else around. The first pitch squeeze chimney felt more like 5.8 to me, though the overall characteristic of this route was like old school Yosemite climbing so some OW/squeeze technique will be helpful. A #4 for the second pitch was definitely helpful for the wide crack and there is a fair amount of fixed gear/slings/cords throughout the route. The 3rd pitch crux can be stemmed through over a nice bolt, but your feet are on some super insecure calcite that is a bit unnerving if you haven't climbed on this rock before (feels like glass). Great summit and a single 70 m rap down Sacred Ground is pretty straight forward. For the first station which is far climbers left from the summit, I aimed for a block about 15-20 ft climbers right of the anchors and walked up an easy ramp to the anchors rather than tried to swing to the anchors. After rappelling, there was a gap in groups on North Chimney so we headed up that for an awesome day of climbing. Both are awesome routes, I think the climbing is slightly better on North Chimney but Kor Ingalls has the history. If you are deciding between the two, I would pick which of these means more to ya...or whichever is open! Oct 26, 2023

I wanted to add a useful piece of information to the descent that I feel is pretty critical and not talked about. After getting to the base  of the North Face rappel, there is still some risky down climbing scrambling to get to the trail. We rapped it in the dark, and once we got to the base it was not at all obvious how to get down, you can't judge depth and most of it is completely cliffed... more I wanted to add a useful piece of information to the descent that I feel is pretty critical and not talked about. After getting to the base  of the North Face rappel, there is still some risky down climbing scrambling to get to the trail. We rapped it in the dark, and once we got to the base it was not at all obvious how to get down, you can't judge depth and most of it is completely cliffed out. A group from North Chimney was there and showed us the way they came up, but it was even difficult for them to find it. I was under the impression that you could walk around the base of the tower to Kor, but we didn't find that to be the case. If you are going to be rapping this in the dark make sure you know how to get down the scramble from North Chimney, you could end up in a pretty dicey situation in the dark. And please correct me if I am missing some information on this, I just haven't seen it mentioned yet. Nov 5, 2023

routes.route_description: The hangout/gear sortin spot, or in our case our last option after being blown off every route and waiting in heinous slug trails of people. All we wanted was some crack. Cruise down to the back side of this betty and get your flappers ready, tight hands to big fists gets ye up this bizzle.
routes.route_location: The hangout boulder beneath the northern side of Castleton. Good views of the North Face and The North Chimney.
routes.route_protection: A fall wouldn't be encouraged as the slope could take your for an unforgettable ride!

route_comments.comment_text: fixin to move to castle valley to be closer to this hog Oct 31, 2017

routes.route_fa: Daniel Burgette, Allen Erickson 4/1970. Second ascent: Jimmy Dunn, Dan Porter 9/1970
routes.route_description: This is probably the easiest route on Castleton, and is a fantastic climb. To reach, hike up the talus as for the Kor-Ingalls, when you reach the base, walk around to the north end of the tower and traverse out on a ledge to the base of the chimney which is right on the left hand corner of the North Face.P1- Climb the double hand cracks in the corner. This pitch is intimidating, but there are many rests. The crux of the pitch is at the top where you climb over a short bulge, and then up to a small ledge to the belay.P2- Climb a short but tricky 5.8 offwidth protected by an old bolt. Place a big cam here instead of clipping the useless bolt. Then climb the chimney above climbing over chockstones and varied cracks to a belay on a small ledge. The belay takes hand size cams.P3- Climb up the hand crack up to a stemming move at the top of the chimney which gets you to a ledge. Climb up easy ground to a ledge where you join the Kor Ingalls. Gear placement can get a little runout after the first 20ft but its easy climbing. After stemming across the ledge, there is a spot at knee height to place a .1 Camalot.P4- Climb the last pitch of the Kor Ingalls to the top.
routes.route_location: N/A
routes.route_protection: Three sets of cams to #3 Camalot, 1 bigger cam for pitch 2.  A set of stoppers.

route_comments.comment_text: I'd give this route at least a 9-.  A 5.8 leader is likely to have issues with two spots in particular. For the rack, take 1 set of nuts and 1 set of cams plus a few extra hand-sized pieces to make protecting the first pitch more straightforward.  A screamer for the bolt on P2 might be wise. While this route climbs an enourmous chimney, it has virtually no chimney climbing.  The P2 OW is... more I'd give this route at least a 9-.  A 5.8 leader is likely to have issues with two spots in particular. For the rack, take 1 set of nuts and 1 set of cams plus a few extra hand-sized pieces to make protecting the first pitch more straightforward.  A screamer for the bolt on P2 might be wise. While this route climbs an enourmous chimney, it has virtually no chimney climbing.  The P2 OW is short and not that bad.  I think a #4 camalot would work there, but I'm not sure as I didn't have one. At the top of the chimney (by the huge chockstone), exit climber's right. Oct 30, 2001

I entered this route at 5.8 because that is what it was originally rated.  I believe that ratings are becoming softer and softer, and all this upgrading of routes, especially in the desert is detrimental to the history of climbing there.  The ratings in the desert are stout, it's always been that way and it needs to continue to be that way.  That is part of the allure of climbing there.  I... more I entered this route at 5.8 because that is what it was originally rated.  I believe that ratings are becoming softer and softer, and all this upgrading of routes, especially in the desert is detrimental to the history of climbing there.  The ratings in the desert are stout, it's always been that way and it needs to continue to be that way.  That is part of the allure of climbing there.  I really don't care much about the numbers, but for the sake of climbing history, I just don't think there should be all this upgrading that is taking place in the newer guidebooks. Ben Oct 31, 2001

A helmet is strongly recommended on this climb as there is a lot of loose junk lying around on pitch 3 - it is very easy to knock stuff off with your rope even if careful.  Of course a helmet is always a good idea in the desert, but I just thought I would mention it as this route tends to get rather crowded. Nov 1, 2001

The climbing definitely felt like 5.9 to me, and both the first and second pitches are rated as such in various guidebooks. While I think climbing history should be honored, it's also conceivable that the first ascentionists, for whatever reason, rated it a grade easier than it should have been. This happens today and it happened back then. Some do it deliberately, some not. But either way, it... more The climbing definitely felt like 5.9 to me, and both the first and second pitches are rated as such in various guidebooks. While I think climbing history should be honored, it's also conceivable that the first ascentionists, for whatever reason, rated it a grade easier than it should have been. This happens today and it happened back then. Some do it deliberately, some not. But either way, it makes sense to update ratings based on how the route feels to the average climber. It's been done to Bastille Crack and Stettner's Ledges, among others, for better or for worse; but in the end I feel it does a service to the climb and to those who climb it to give it a rating that's as accurate as possible. As for gear, doubles of cams up to a #3 Camalot and a set of stoppers(rarely used), plus a #4 Camalot worked well for me. I also used a screamer on the old and extremely sketchy-looking bolt, which I backed up with the #4, however, if you have a #4.5 you'll be able to get it in at about bolt-level, instead of having to go a little higher to place the #4. Also, the anchor at the top of pitch 2 is fixed with 2 pins and an old cam or something. Be extra careful when pulling on to the ledge as you exit the main chimney on pitch 3 as it's littered with rocks of all sizes right to the edge, and the jumble of chockstones above this, just before the belay ledge looks like an accident waiting to happen. Dec 19, 2001

Technically, I thought this was easier than the Kor-Ingalls, but more sustained overall. I could see a 5.8 grade, albeit a hard, sustained 5.8. To my surprise I actually liked Kor-Ingalls better overall, although the first pitch of North Chimney was the best on either route. Feb 19, 2002
I agree with Charles, this climb is definitely easier than the Kor-Ingalls.  And please, lets reserve personal attacks for email. Feb 20, 2002

I thought the route was really sustained 5.8 with a 5.9 move at the top of pitch one and another at the bolt on pitch 2.  All in all, I thought it was much easier than Kor-Ingalls, and also much much better.  Fantastic route. Mar 25, 2002

just a quick little something.  i climbed this route a couple of springs ago, and found it to be very nice.  i did happen to bring a #4 with me and it was very nice right at that old spinner.  some dude and his girlfriend who tried to race past us as we were gearing up scorned me for bringing it, but as we were heading up the last part of the chimney i could hear him below cursing as his #3... more just a quick little something.  i climbed this route a couple of springs ago, and found it to be very nice.  i did happen to bring a #4 with me and it was very nice right at that old spinner.  some dude and his girlfriend who tried to race past us as we were gearing up scorned me for bringing it, but as we were heading up the last part of the chimney i could hear him below cursing as his #3 was just a little small.  the move isn't bad there, but some added pro never hurt anyone. Dec 31, 2002

I just wanted to thank my climbing partner Paul C for leading the entire climb for me as this was my first tower and it was bone chilling cccoold. The ambient temperature was around 40 f and a chilling wind roared up that shaded chimney the entire climb, we lost feelings in our fingers and toes. You never trusted your feet and fingers were to stiff to fiddle with gear. Every move became... more I just wanted to thank my climbing partner Paul C for leading the entire climb for me as this was my first tower and it was bone chilling cccoold. The ambient temperature was around 40 f and a chilling wind roared up that shaded chimney the entire climb, we lost feelings in our fingers and toes. You never trusted your feet and fingers were to stiff to fiddle with gear. Every move became incredibly hard and this was the first time in 3 years I ever worried about Paul on lead. The only comforting thoughts were the hot tub he promised would be at the top, me climbing this tourist style (climbing second) and he's climbed this 4 times before. As for anyone new to this type of climbing I would recommend you never climb in this type of cold, it's just not fun and it is simply dangerous for the lead. As far as the climb itself anyone new to offwidths should practice on a few before you do this. This was my first time feeling stuck but kinda happy I was stuck so I won't fall but at the same time worrying I may not make it up and my lead would have to climb down and rescue/laugh at me.  What a strange feeling. Oh and for anyone new to this type of exposure the rap off the North side is nuts but fun. Again, Thanks Paul! Mar 31, 2003

Superb crack climb.  Sustained at 5.7/5.8 with a few slightly more difficult moves and pretty sewn up except for the OW on the second pitch which is quite awkward. I'd recommend continuing to the top from the 2nd belay and doing in 3 pitches total unless the sun is really baking (great shade in the corridor before the last pitch) or there is a party on Kor-Ingalls. We rapped the North... more Superb crack climb.  Sustained at 5.7/5.8 with a few slightly more difficult moves and pretty sewn up except for the OW on the second pitch which is quite awkward. I'd recommend continuing to the top from the 2nd belay and doing in 3 pitches total unless the sun is really baking (great shade in the corridor before the last pitch) or there is a party on Kor-Ingalls. We rapped the North Face and it took four single 60m rope rappels.  The distance for the last rap was about 110' and required a short down climb. For a rack, I took:  Stoppers- 1 set, Cams- (singles) green alien through .75 Camalot, two red, two yellow Camalots, and one 3 and 3.5 Camalot.  If I did the route again, I'd leave the 3.5 behind.  I felt fine on the OW without a giant cam and I'm not a particularly bold leader. May 29, 2003

I don't think it's a question so much of being a bold leader, but simply that there is no other good pro if you don't have the #4 camalot (or something bigger) at the crux of pitch 2.  The bolt is terrible, much worse for example than the bolts on Kor-Ingalls.  If it pulls, you might fall down past your belayer and almost certainly get hurt.  I too felt very solid on this section--it didn't... more I don't think it's a question so much of being a bold leader, but simply that there is no other good pro if you don't have the #4 camalot (or something bigger) at the crux of pitch 2.  The bolt is terrible, much worse for example than the bolts on Kor-Ingalls.  If it pulls, you might fall down past your belayer and almost certainly get hurt.  I too felt very solid on this section--it didn't seem too hard--but I was happy to have the #4, given that I considered it my only real pro here.  I'd recommend at least that anyone who leads in the 5.9/10 range take it--if you feel at all insecure on this section (which some consider the route crux), you'll be glad. May 29, 2003

Charles, you are definitely right about the bolt being terrible.  It looks like it has already seen some hard falls and is probably ready to succumb to the next one; or maybe not, but I wouldn't want to test it.  Does a #4 Camalot even fit in this crack?  It looks much too wide even for a #4.5. I own a #4.5 but not the #4.  I agonized over whether or not to bring it right up until we... more Charles, you are definitely right about the bolt being terrible.  It looks like it has already seen some hard falls and is probably ready to succumb to the next one; or maybe not, but I wouldn't want to test it.  Does a #4 Camalot even fit in this crack?  It looks much too wide even for a #4.5. I own a #4.5 but not the #4.  I agonized over whether or not to bring it right up until we started hiking and ultimately decided againsed it.  We were trying to be fast and light since temps were getting up to 100* on Tuesday.  We were back at the van by 11:30am, thankfully.  But, I surly would have been glad if I had the 4.5 at the time... If you find yourself here w/o a large cam, a medium sized piece can be plugged into the crack, eight or so feet below the bolt (deep in a chimney).  Not the best placement but better than nothing. May 29, 2003

My girlfriend and I climbed the first two pitches on this route last Friday.  (Thundering skys convinced us to back off at the top of the second pitch.)  I would certainly give the first two pitches three stars as they were fun, contained a variety of moves, and kept me honest. After reading all the debate on this page regarding which cams to bring or leave behind, and since I am a much... more My girlfriend and I climbed the first two pitches on this route last Friday.  (Thundering skys convinced us to back off at the top of the second pitch.)  I would certainly give the first two pitches three stars as they were fun, contained a variety of moves, and kept me honest. After reading all the debate on this page regarding which cams to bring or leave behind, and since I am a much better hiker than climber, I brought both a #4.5 and #4 camalot on this climb.  As stated above, the 4.5 fits great right at the bolt.  I walked the 4.5 up until I could reach up and slide the #4 in.  I then walked the #4 up and placed it behind a chockstone with a long runner.  The 4.5 would have made a great first piece of gear right off the second belay as well.  I enjoyed the security of having the 4.5 in addition to the old bolt while sliding up that OW.  Not everyone needs that kind of security.  It is a nasty fall though if that bolt were to shear and you didn't have it backed up with anything. As far as the rating goes I would call the route sustained 5.8 with two 5.9 cruxes.  We were actually surprised at how sustained the first pitch felt even with so many great rest stances. GREAT climb! The first pitch is so good. Handjam after handjam for 160 feet. Plenty of rests and plenty of pro. The crux of P-1 is definately the bulge at the top. The pitch 2 offwidth crux was not nearly as bad as i thought it would be (and i have flailed on a 5.7 ow in lcc). However, this route keeps coming at you! Don't be fooled into thinking you are done with it after the crux, as there... more GREAT climb! The first pitch is so good. Handjam after handjam for 160 feet. Plenty of rests and plenty of pro. The crux of P-1 is definately the bulge at the top. The pitch 2 offwidth crux was not nearly as bad as i thought it would be (and i have flailed on a 5.7 ow in lcc). However, this route keeps coming at you! Don't be fooled into thinking you are done with it after the crux, as there are plenty of 5.8 moves left. WARNING! About twenty feet up the third pitch you will see two sets of slings on the left wall above the giant chockstone. Pretend they are not there! I stepped across to the left wall, made some moves on top of it and found myself quickly off route. To get back on route i walked across the chockstone. That was, uhhh, thrilling. Just stay IN the chimney even though it looks kinda crappy. P-4 belay is the obvious flat spot between the main tower and the pillar to yr left. There are no anchors. P-4 is about the last forty feet of the Kor-Ingalls route and is full of sweet and easy face moves with HUGE exposure. What a blast. We did it in december on a clear day, upper 50's with no wind. I wouldn't go much colder than that. Dec 13, 2004

Did the N. Chimney on 10/13/06.  The first pitch is excellent, though the crux is probably among the hardest "5.8" moves I've encountered.  The 2nd pitch OW isn't too bad, but the bolt "protecting" the OW is a 1/4 inch starhead drive in, half way out and bent!  I was glad to have a #4 Camalot...a second #4 or a #4.5-5 Camalot (older style Camalot sizes...not C4) could be placed on this pitch... more Did the N. Chimney on 10/13/06.  The first pitch is excellent, though the crux is probably among the hardest "5.8" moves I've encountered.  The 2nd pitch OW isn't too bad, but the bolt "protecting" the OW is a 1/4 inch starhead drive in, half way out and bent!  I was glad to have a #4 Camalot...a second #4 or a #4.5-5 Camalot (older style Camalot sizes...not C4) could be placed on this pitch if OW scares you.  Be prepared to backup the "anchor" atop pitch 2.  It consists of 2 marginal pins.   I fixed a #10 hex to back up the bong.  There are PILES of loose rock on the ledges at the top of the 3rd pitch chimney...if you're there when no one else is around, toss some off!  The route was very dirty the day we did it, perhaps due to the epic rains the week before.  Overall, I enjoyed this route, but thought the Kor-Ingalls was more memorable.  Save the N.Chimney for a HOT day, and enjoy the sun and scenery on the K/I when temps are cool to moderate! Oct 16, 2006

As my first desert tower this climb will Always be special to me even though I almost died. Enthralled by Moab and eager to climb after a couple of days at the Creek.  I buddied up with these guys Scott And Adam who I'd met at Potash Road. I led the first pitch but when Scott was half way up he got a bad feeling and told me to lower him off despite my protests. (Later I was soo glad he did).... more As my first desert tower this climb will Always be special to me even though I almost died. Enthralled by Moab and eager to climb after a couple of days at the Creek.  I buddied up with these guys Scott And Adam who I'd met at Potash Road. I led the first pitch but when Scott was half way up he got a bad feeling and told me to lower him off despite my protests. (Later I was soo glad he did). Instead Adam came up climbing quickly and efficiently. I led the second and was so impressed that I handed him the rack for the third. About fifty feet up the third pitch Adam accidentally kicked a couple of milk crate sized blocks lose that wizzed passed me by inches. Startled I screamed ROCK ROCK ROCK and Scott barely got out of the way at the base as the Rocks smashed onto the large boulder at the base. Thank God he prophetically lowered as one of us would have surely been hit at the top of the second pitch. Shaken but OK we summited only to find that our second rope had been cut over half way thru by the rockfall. The mini-epic continued when our good rope got stuck on the rappel and I made the decision to leave it as darkness was now setting in. (unknowingly we rapped the chimney instead of the Kor-Ingalls, Rap K-I or N. face) We now had to rap the last two pitches with a rope that was marginal at best. I remember rapping off the end of the rope at the same time I grabbed the slings at the top of the first pitch for the rope was barely long enough. I must have the best guardian angel out there because we all survived intact. I actually went back the next day and bribed the only two climbers there to recover my new supersafe from the route. In closing, the route is great but be ever vigilant for large loose blocks littering the upper pitches. I had my helmet on but it wouldn't have mattered given the size of these blocks. Jan 13, 2007

Great climb, fantastic summit. We linked pitches 3&4 together, which made for 3 nice long pitches for the route. A 4.5 was key for the OW on P2. I climbed both the North Chimney and K-I on the same day back in April. The climbs are honestly like twins both formed from the same crack running through the entire formation it seems. K-I gets sun most of the day and was fairly sustained but I never felt like the moves got past 5.8. The questionable bolts on the infamous crux pitch had other gear nearby and were therefore not as scary as I... more I climbed both the North Chimney and K-I on the same day back in April. The climbs are honestly like twins both formed from the same crack running through the entire formation it seems. K-I gets sun most of the day and was fairly sustained but I never felt like the moves got past 5.8. The questionable bolts on the infamous crux pitch had other gear nearby and were therefore not as scary as I thought they would be. North Chimney on the other hand didn't feel very sustained but the cruxes were pretty in my face. It was also cold and windy on that side of the formation, probably better to climb it on a hot day. I also never felt any of the moves got above 5.8 although it was a little strenuous and awkward at the beginning of each pitch. I lead the second pitch since I got the classic pitch on K-I and that spinning sheet metal hanger with not other gear in made me nervous. I might have gotten a little tunnel vision because I didn't see any other gear for a while and was practically pissing my pants. All in all I'd say both climbs are in the 5.8+/5.9- area. The crux of K-I is more technical I felt and was two moves that I could say felt 5.9. The North Chimney was just thuggery and the moves were mostly difficult in that I had to squeeze my little ass up there with my knees by my ears half the time. K-I is higher quality in some ways but much more crowded. Although when I climbed it we actually ended up waiting for two parties on the North Chimney and we only had to wait for one on K-I. Jun 15, 2009

Climbed this route last Thursday with my wife, very fun! Rack: doubles to #1 C4, triples 2/3 C4, 1 #4, 1#5.  The triples felt adequate on the first pitch as I placed a few more 3's towards the bottom and the majority of the 2's near the end of the pitch.  Used the #5 C4 at the bolt on the 2nd pitch and the 4 later in the 2nd pitch. The Climb: Excellent first pitch! After multiple days at... more Climbed this route last Thursday with my wife, very fun! Rack: doubles to #1 C4, triples 2/3 C4, 1 #4, 1#5.  The triples felt adequate on the first pitch as I placed a few more 3's towards the bottom and the majority of the 2's near the end of the pitch.  Used the #5 C4 at the bolt on the 2nd pitch and the 4 later in the 2nd pitch. The Climb: Excellent first pitch! After multiple days at the creek this pitch felt much easier than what I was expecting, I agree with the statement that there are multiple 5.8 moves but with really good rests, just keep your eyes out for feet and be creative.  Crux wasn't bad at all, really good gear just keep getting your feet up. Belay at bolts 5.8 2nd pitch wide from the get go and with a manky bolt to boot! I wouldn't trust that thing, just have your 2nd haul the 5 for the rest of the route and feel confident in the fact that you don't need to use this thing.  Overall the wide moves weren't bad just trust your feet and it'll be over before you know it.  This pitch varied several times for me and I actually felt like this pitch was harder than the first.  I don't know if that was from the fact that i'd been climbing in the creek for the week so the first pitch was easy or the fact that this pitch was more mentally taxing because I felt like I was going to die from a chockstone at any second!  At the very end of the chimney climb to the right under the massive chockstone and build a belay on a small ledge.  Belay for me took a 1, .5 and blue tcu.  Careful to not knock rocks off the ledge.  5.8+ 3rd pitch was the forgettable one of the climb which we linked into the last for a great final pitch.  The north chimney pitch ascends the corner under a big chockstone to a ledge where it joins with the KI.  The last pitch of the KI gives you great flake face climbing up over some exposure to the bolted belay just below the top.  Really a fun way to finish the route after climbing up the forgettable 3rd pitch.  Definitely combine 3 & 4. Spent some time on the summit and then did 3 double 60M rope raps down the North Face to the bags. Overall a great way to summit castleton and in my opinion more than the first pitch is worth the trip I can honestly say i've never climbed anything like the 2nd pitch, go to the summit! Oct 18, 2010

I spent a full season right next to North Chimney and saw most parties show up without the #5. They then complained, as they should, when they got to to "the move". I even saw one group that brought the #5 to the base, but then decided not to take it on the route. Just carry the big cam, people. The rating is "old school" 5.8. I'd call it 10- now. And one more time, the discussion... more I spent a full season right next to North Chimney and saw most parties show up without the #5. They then complained, as they should, when they got to to "the move". I even saw one group that brought the #5 to the base, but then decided not to take it on the route. Just carry the big cam, people. The rating is "old school" 5.8. I'd call it 10- now. And one more time, the discussion of replacing the bolt is not about safety. With the cam you have safety. Its about convenience. Its more convenient to clip a bolt than place a cam, so people want the bolt. I again say that the bolt is not necessary and FA did not have it. He also didn't have any cams and lacked sticky rubber. So carry the cam and ignore the bolt. The really bad bolt. In my opinion, if you find 10- desert pretty hard, your rack should be a double set of cams with a couple extra wide hands pieces and maybe cut down on the finger pieces, four slings with biners, and perhaps a small set of nuts. One number five will work... Jun 16, 2012

P2 beyond the OW seemed the worst with loose death blocks. P3 was fine in that regard. OW is fun and climbs much differently than the one on Kor-Ingalls. Regarding pro for the OW, I brought a #5 & #4 C4 Camalot. A #4 isn't that necessary if you brought a #5, but I would have preferred a #6. Seriously, while you can get by with a smaller large cam, if you have a #6 you will be happier to have that along, as otherwise you have to climb about half of the offwidth (and toughest part IMO) before you can get the #5 in as your first real piece of gear on the pitch. OW isn't that tricky as long as you aren't afraid of slipping on the calcite. May 4, 2013

I wouldn't plan on it staying there and you should def bring one of your own along. There's also a stuck nut just below the crux at the top of pitch one that I used. A few random thoughts - I thought it was really sustained climbing - especially the endless jamming on pitch 1 - super fun, pitch 2 utilizes your chimney technique for sure, the stepover on pitch 3 is pretty heady when the chimney runs out, we did 3 double 60m rope raps to get down the north face - the ledges and chains are nice - don't miss the second one out to your right as you descend, YES a big bro works nicely to protect the OW on pitch 2, if you want to sew up pitch 1 you can bring 4 #3's and you will use them all... Climbed on 03/19/2016 - My two cents on the route: It was amazing! If you love to go HAM on hand cracks, then this is the route for you. If you are like me and get nervous running it out in the dessert, you wont regret having triples for hand size pro on P1. That being said, it is also easy to protect with finger size pieces if you don't have triples for hands. Also, we brought a #6 and were... more Climbed on 03/19/2016 - My two cents on the route: It was amazing! If you love to go HAM on hand cracks, then this is the route for you. If you are like me and get nervous running it out in the dessert, you wont regret having triples for hand size pro on P1. That being said, it is also easy to protect with finger size pieces if you don't have triples for hands. Also, we brought a #6 and were very happy to place it right by the bolt in P2. It fit like a glove and made the awkward stemming a lot more comfortable. We got confused where P2 actually ended and the belay for P3 began, so we ended up just building a belay at the very top of the chimney.  It seems like it would have been much better to belay where the two pitons are (one in the left crack, one in the right). This might be obvious to everyone else, but it wasn't for me, so I thought I'd mention it. From there, it's pretty easy to go all the way to the summit, just bring some slings to reduce the drag. We rapped the North Face route in two raps with two 70 meter ropes tied together. We went from the summit to the first set of chains at a nice ledge, and from there to the ground. If you want to not drag a second rope with you to the summit, just wait up there until another party shows up and rap with them. Mar 21, 2016

Due to the various comments about rapping with single or double ropes, I've done both so here is my experience: You can rap the North Face route with a single 70m, requiring 4 raps. Rap 1 goes from the top of the tower to a set of intermediate rap bolts about 30-40 feet down and to climbers left. Rap 2 goes from those bolts to a nice ledge with chains. Rap 3 goes to another ledge with nice... more Due to the various comments about rapping with single or double ropes, I've done both so here is my experience: You can rap the North Face route with a single 70m, requiring 4 raps. Rap 1 goes from the top of the tower to a set of intermediate rap bolts about 30-40 feet down and to climbers left. Rap 2 goes from those bolts to a nice ledge with chains. Rap 3 goes to another ledge with nice chains, and rap 4 makes it to the bottom, with a few feet extra to spare. I don't think you could do this with a 60M. DO NOT try go from the summit to the first ledge in a single rap, missing the intermediate rap bolts, or you'll find yourself a few feet short of the chains. If you have double 70M ropes, you can go from the summit to the first ledge (first set of chains, skipping the intermediate rap bolts), and from that ledge you can go to the ground. Hope this is helpful Sep 25, 2017

^^^^^ Seriously take a look at this comment before rapping, especially in the dark on your first trip up the tower! We had a single 70m rope and we're heading down the North face route but didn't know to go to the first set of chains that are, apparently, well to the left on the first rappel. For the first rappel we  had to stop on a ledge about 10 feet up and 30 feet right of the chains.... more ^^^^^ Seriously take a look at this comment before rapping, especially in the dark on your first trip up the tower! We had a single 70m rope and we're heading down the North face route but didn't know to go to the first set of chains that are, apparently, well to the left on the first rappel. For the first rappel we  had to stop on a ledge about 10 feet up and 30 feet right of the chains. Fortunately, I had most of the rack, so I built an anchor, my partner lowered down, we pulled the rope and we belayed each other over to the chains. The rest of the rappels on the North face are pretty straight-forward. Moral of the story: if you only have one 70m rope, stop after probably 20 ft and look for chains that are supposedly on your left, don't rappel the full rope length on the first rappel. Oct 15, 2017

We linked pitch two and part of pitch three stopping at the optional belay before joining pitch four of Kor-Ingalls. It is 25-30 ft. to the right of the plum line, and not very obvious. I accidentally passed it... more Just to reiterate previous comments regarding the descent via the North Face: 1st Rappel (from the summit anchors) -- Straight forward. The next set of anchors are true to the plum line and pretty obvious. 2nd Rappel -- After about 40-50 ft, be looking to the climber's right for the next anchor. It is 25-30 ft. to the right of the plum line, and not very obvious. I accidentally passed it and had to ascend back up 10-15 ft. From here you can reach the ground with two 70 m ropes. We brought twin 70 m ropes, so we had no issues after the fact, but I don't recall seeing another anchor below the 2nd mid-way anchor. I'm sure one exists but I didn't see it. Dec 15, 2017

Our guide book (high on moab) said that it was possible to descend the... more I climbed this route 2 days ago 11/20/2018, besides the bird shit covered death blocks found within the chimney, it is a great route! All of it felt like solid old man 5.9. I was very glad to have along a 4 and 5 camalot. The anchor on top of p2 are 2 old pitons, which can be backed up with a size 2  and/or .3/.4 camalot. Our guide book (high on moab) said that it was possible to descend the north face in 4 raps with a single 70 m, don't believe it! We were just about 10 feet short of the next set of rap chains. It deposits you on a ledge from where you can then downclimb unroped (or make another anchor by slinging a flake or leaving gear) over super exposed low 5th class terrain to the next ledge and the next set of anchors. I'd recommend bringing another rope or a tag line, you'll be happy you did. It turns out that unless you have recently updated the MP app on your phone the most recent comments don't show up, would have loved to have read some of the previous comments before climbing the route. There are a few sections that are harder than 5.8. The first 10ft of pitch 1 seems to be the most difficult. I've done this route 6 times on ropes in addition to a lead solo, daisy solo, and free solo. For a regular lead and lead solo rack: 1x .3 1x .4 1x .5 2x .75 2x #1s 2x #2s 2x #3s 1x #4 1x #6 4x alpine draws Don't bring a #5, just bump your #6 through the first 10ft of... more There are a few sections that are harder than 5.8. The first 10ft of pitch 1 seems to be the most difficult. I've done this route 6 times on ropes in addition to a lead solo, daisy solo, and free solo. For a regular lead and lead solo rack: 1x .3 1x .4 1x .5 2x .75 2x #1s 2x #2s 2x #3s 1x #4 1x #6 4x alpine draws Don't bring a #5, just bump your #6 through the first 10ft of pitch 2 Don't bring nuts unless you like to place pro every 6 inches For daisy solo rack: 1x .3 1x .4 1x .5 1x .75 2x #1s 1x #2 (but a hand jam is as good as a belay so you could leave the #2 home) ;) 1x #3 1x #4 1x #6 Decent: >North Face double rap- Rap down the North Face in two double rope raps with 70m ropes (Best Climbs Moab says its 3 raps but this it is possible in 2). If you're doing this, first rappel is to the first set of belay anchors (belay ledge for pitch 3 of North Face). Second rap gets your to the ground. You can do this with two 60m ropes but the second rap is a stretch, tie knots in the end of the rope! >North Face single rap-Rap down the North Face in three single rope raps with a 70m rope but the first rappel is a stretch, tie knots in the end of the rope! >Kor-Ingals- I have only rappelled Kor-Ingals with an 80m rope so I can't say what's possible with a 70m or 60m. Its 4 raps down. After you rap the off width pitch, give the rope a good tug when gravity starts to take it to ensure it does not get stuck. *** I have got ropes stuck multiple times rapping both the North Face and Kor-Ingals, use good rope management *** Mar 26, 2020
#6 coming off anchor on P2 is nice if you have it!! P3 belay takes hand-sized cam to back up pitons May 22, 2020

Warning: near the bulge crux at the end of P1 there is a detached block.  What appears to be a small (.4 and below) double crack in the corner that runs for about 10 ft. under the bulge is in reality a large detached block.  It won't fall, but don't trust it for pro.  I placed a .4 and weighted it, causing the block to slightly move and my piece popped out, sending me on a 30 ft. whipper to a... more Warning: near the bulge crux at the end of P1 there is a detached block.  What appears to be a small (.4 and below) double crack in the corner that runs for about 10 ft. under the bulge is in reality a large detached block.  It won't fall, but don't trust it for pro.  I placed a .4 and weighted it, causing the block to slightly move and my piece popped out, sending me on a 30 ft. whipper to a bomber #3.  I was fine and finished the climb. Apr 26, 2021

Regarding large gear, I brought a green big bro which is basically a 6. We also had 3 blues, 3 yellows, a 4 and a 5, plus a normal rack. I led pitch 2. That move at the bolt is quite polished but it does go with a side pull (gaston) on an edge inside the crack. I think I may have used the 5 there to supplement the Big Bro and the bolt, but I took the 5 up with me after the move. I walked that... more Regarding large gear, I brought a green big bro which is basically a 6. We also had 3 blues, 3 yellows, a 4 and a 5, plus a normal rack. I led pitch 2. That move at the bolt is quite polished but it does go with a side pull (gaston) on an edge inside the crack. I think I may have used the 5 there to supplement the Big Bro and the bolt, but I took the 5 up with me after the move. I walked that 5 up the next 100 feet, ended using it at the belay. I loved having it above me through the many glassy smooth chimney sections. We spent 17 hours car to car  on the climb, but we are both in our later sixties and move slowly. Don't be like me and forget your headlamp! May 15, 2021

Maybe replace the star bolt with another one that isn’t rusty and half way out, just like the good old days. Oh that’s right they stopped making that garbage. With that said, I felt fine with a BD #5 a foot above the antique. It’s almost maxed out so bring a #6 if you want to, either works. May 26, 2021

We followed Corey and his brother up this route - funny! Hey Corey. We used a 6. EZ and super safe to skate it up all the way from the belay to past the bolt. Trip report here: medium.com/core-shot/climbi… May 27, 2021

In a recent discussion with Renny Jackson the topic of the bolt on P2 came up.  He had assumed that I had placed it on the first ascent.  I wasn’t aware of it until I climbed the route again many years later with my kids.  I wasn’t excited to see the bolt, especially since it seemed manky.  But it is there.  And if it is removed there will still be a man made hole in the rock.  At this point... more In a recent discussion with Renny Jackson the topic of the bolt on P2 came up.  He had assumed that I had placed it on the first ascent.  I wasn’t aware of it until I climbed the route again many years later with my kids.  I wasn’t excited to see the bolt, especially since it seemed manky.  But it is there.  And if it is removed there will still be a man made hole in the rock.  At this point with all of the traffic on the route, I would support someone replacing the bolt, using the same hole location, with a modern 1/2” 4” long bolt that folks can trust. I see on here that there is a lot of discussion about the route being 5.8 or 5.9.  The 5.8 rating comes from my route description in the AAJ.  Some history is needed.  The hardest route I had climbed was the North Ridge of the Grand Teton the previous summer that was rated 5.7.  I was really strong from driving truck that winter and had a stellar day when I climbed the North Chimney.  I knew that it was harder than the North Ridge, so I rated it 5.8.  I didn’t have a clue about 5.9. It is a wonderful route.  More trivia about the first ascent is in my article in Summit magazine. Jul 26, 2021

The offwidth section is hard. Prepare yourself. A number 6 would be better than a 5, and the 5 can come in handy higher up too. As for the rappels, rapping on a single side of a 70m rope with a biner block would totally get you down to the second set of anchors. This was our original plan, but we teamed up with another group to share ropes for the rappel. If you extended your 70m rope about... more The offwidth section is hard. Prepare yourself. A number 6 would be better than a 5, and the 5 can come in handy higher up too. As for the rappels, rapping on a single side of a 70m rope with a biner block would totally get you down to the second set of anchors. This was our original plan, but we teamed up with another group to share ropes for the rappel. If you extended your 70m rope about 40’ off center, set up a biner block, and then extended the other side of the rope with a couple of long (untied) cordalettes tied together to pull on, you wouldn’t need a second rope to rappel. The rappel is super clean, so no worries with the Biner block and knot getting snagged. From the second set of anchors, the 70m rope will do it alive in two more raps. Oct 24, 2021
Just a heads-up, in early November 2021 when we were climbing Fine Jade, I think there was a good size rock fall on North Chimney.  Climbing parties were all fine as far as we can tell. Dec 4, 2021

There are too many comments for this route, therefore I will add another. 3 x #3 C4 cams are recommended for P1. I only brought 2 and had to down climb to grab one and bump it a long way after. If you save 2 x #0.75 cams, you can place one before and then after the tricky crux at the end of this first pitch. The #6 C4 cam protects the most difficult moves by the bolt on P2. (I think... more There are too many comments for this route, therefore I will add another. 3 x #3 C4 cams are recommended for P1. I only brought 2 and had to down climb to grab one and bump it a long way after. If you save 2 x #0.75 cams, you can place one before and then after the tricky crux at the end of this first pitch. The #6 C4 cam protects the most difficult moves by the bolt on P2. (I think there was some confusion above as older comments reference the old "Camalot" style sizes.) The crack narrows above the bolt and if you want to stay on TR the whole time, bring a #5 C4 cam to continue bumping. However, a finger cam may be placed a bit higher and therefore I agree with others that the #6 is adequate on its own. I believe the route has cleaned up over time as the first 2 pitches are clean and spectacular -- reminiscent of the upper pitches of Northeast Buttress, Higher Cathedral Rock in Yosemite. There are loose rocks on P3 that warrant caution but they are not in a place you or the rope would likely touch. P.S. For me, this route got about 10x more awesome when I realized it's the one Steph Davis solos at the beginning of this sublime little climbing movie: youtube.com/watch?v=hz5w7q5… Mar 27, 2022

Layton B's gear beta would be perfect for someone slightly more experienced than me.  The #6 was essential and I appreciated having some triples from a #1 and #3 for the first pitch. I felt heavy starting the first pitch but used almost all my gear by the end. If you're pushing yourself at this grade take all the rests. I did the second pitch OW with my back towards The Rectory and it went. My... more Layton B's gear beta would be perfect for someone slightly more experienced than me.  The #6 was essential and I appreciated having some triples from a #1 and #3 for the first pitch. I felt heavy starting the first pitch but used almost all my gear by the end. If you're pushing yourself at this grade take all the rests. I did the second pitch OW with my back towards The Rectory and it went. My first OW. Not too much bird poop on the last pitch, pretty clean overall. If possible, make sure you stand as far back from the tower when you pull your ropes from the last rap to avoid getting them stuck. May 21, 2022

Bailed off this route after Pitch 1 because of lightning and thunderstorms rolling into the valley. If you rap from the Pitch 1 anchors with 2 ropes (which I believe is typically necessary) - the knot tying them together WILL almost certainly get stuck in the crack (at the crux bulge) as you try to pull them. We had to climb the pitch again to fix this. This could have been avoided the first... more Bailed off this route after Pitch 1 because of lightning and thunderstorms rolling into the valley. If you rap from the Pitch 1 anchors with 2 ropes (which I believe is typically necessary) - the knot tying them together WILL almost certainly get stuck in the crack (at the crux bulge) as you try to pull them. We had to climb the pitch again to fix this. This could have been avoided the first time by doing the following: First member(s) of the party rap the route normally. Then have them pull the knot-side rope down with the assistance of the person at the top until the knot is below the bulge where the rope falls into the crack. The person at the bottom then fixes the side of the rope with the knot to a block on the ground (or to themselves) so that the person on top can descend the strand without the knot. Once everyone is on the ground, continue pulling the rope on the side with the knot. Our rope-end STILL got hung up in that spot after it came through the chains, but luckily because there was no knot we were able to tug it through. Hopefully this can help someone who finds themselves in a similar situation! Jun 3, 2022

P1 - I thought it was too long to rap with a 70m, but the next comment says you can, so it must be 110' or 115'. P2 is around 130' to the two fixed pitons (easy to back up with a cam or 2) P3 & P4 can be linked into a single pitch about 125' long (or two shorter pitches). On the rating:  See Dan Burgette's comments above (He was FA)  The north ridge of The Grand was upgraded from 5.7 to... more P1 - I thought it was too long to rap with a 70m, but the next comment says you can, so it must be 110' or 115'. P2 is around 130' to the two fixed pitons (easy to back up with a cam or 2) P3 & P4 can be linked into a single pitch about 125' long (or two shorter pitches). On the rating:  See Dan Burgette's comments above (He was FA)  The north ridge of The Grand was upgraded from 5.7 to 5.8 after he climbed it, and he thought the north chimney was harder.  P1 and P2 are long with a lot of old-style 5.8 climbing and both have 5.9 cruxes.  Go warmup on Bloody Elbows and Bloody Knees at the Dihedrals on the River.  Both are old-style 5.9 cracks; feel like the same grade as P1 and P2 on North Chimney. Take the #6. A set of twin 60m ropes gets down the North Face in 2 raps nicely.  1st rap is 130' straight down to a ledge with chains, and the 2nd is 200' down to the start of the North Face routes.  Rope stretch will give you 5 extra feet at the bottom, but tie knots.  See Jay Smith's rap topo in the hotlink just under the Descent heading.  It is spot-on. Jun 7, 2022

Hey Jefe, my partner and I climbed the first pitch of the North Chimney last year and we had to end up rapping off the first pitch from the bolted belay with a 70m. A 70m WILL get you to the ground with rope stretch, make sure to tie knots!! Also like the description says, a #5 is almost a must and a #6 was nice as well. I would not have liked that offwidth without the 5. That bolt was... more Hey Jefe, my partner and I climbed the first pitch of the North Chimney last year and we had to end up rapping off the first pitch from the bolted belay with a 70m. A 70m WILL get you to the ground with rope stretch, make sure to tie knots!! Also like the description says, a #5 is almost a must and a #6 was nice as well. I would not have liked that offwidth without the 5. That bolt was definitely not looking like it would hold a fall. Lightning struck the tower in early October 2022 which may or may not have loosened some blocks in the chimney. Be wary about what you grab, there are some microwave sized blocks just waiting to be trundled on p2 and 3. Oct 12, 2022

We climbed this route in late April in fine conditions.  Some thoughts: -Pitch 1 was the crux for me, probably because I like chimney climbing and I hadn’t led anything in almost a year.  The crux bulge wasn’t all that bad; I pulled it without thinking too hard.  I just found the pitch to be sustained.  I agree with others that the hardest part was getting off the ground. -There’s a large... more We climbed this route in late April in fine conditions.  Some thoughts: -Pitch 1 was the crux for me, probably because I like chimney climbing and I hadn’t led anything in almost a year.  The crux bulge wasn’t all that bad; I pulled it without thinking too hard.  I just found the pitch to be sustained.  I agree with others that the hardest part was getting off the ground. -There’s a large block below the P1 crux bulge with a tapering #1 crack that looks inviting, but it moves.  There’s a far better #2 placement in the crux above, but you need to get into the crux to place it. -The OW wasn’t bad (the bulge higher in the chimney felt harder).  I can’t see how you could get a #5 to work near the relic bolt without getting into the business. -Speaking of the #5, I found myself 50 feet past the offwidth wishing I had back cleaned it - you could bump it in the right crack almost all the way to the belay.  Other gear exists in the chimney, but is more tricky. -There’s a fixed bong at the P2 belay.  Hand size and finger size pieces can be made to work for this anchor. -We rapped the K-I with two 70s in two raps from summit to base.  K-I seems a better choice if it’s windy. All in all a great route!  I agree with Sam Lightner that the modern rating is 5.10ish.  The "desert tower" 5.8+ rating is fair. I’ll be back for sure to climb the south side! May 2, 2023

Heady and sustained lead for 5.9 for sure! Linking pitches 2 and 3 (manage the drag a bit) with 60m is pretty good, you will get to the notch that joins the Kor-Ingall. It is after the step across and continues up a bit. I sling the big rock for the anchor. Really awesome and comfy spot to belay. The chimney below has many loose rocks (many are marked, and lots are not). Personally, I tried to... more Heady and sustained lead for 5.9 for sure! Linking pitches 2 and 3 (manage the drag a bit) with 60m is pretty good, you will get to the notch that joins the Kor-Ingall. It is after the step across and continues up a bit. I sling the big rock for the anchor. Really awesome and comfy spot to belay. The chimney below has many loose rocks (many are marked, and lots are not). Personally, I tried to avoid being in it. Double rope rap (2x60m) will get you to the ground at the anchor(the same anchor you used at the top) in two raps. Carry the #5! Oct 23, 2023

Phenomenal route that we did after finishing Kor-Ingalls and rapped down from the summit. This route seemed to be more popular though it could have just been the day. The first pitch was awesome, sustained crack climbing with a little bit of everything and I would definitely put at 5.9. I found the initial moves off the ground to be the hardest, with the bulge before the anchors being almost... more Phenomenal route that we did after finishing Kor-Ingalls and rapped down from the summit. This route seemed to be more popular though it could have just been the day. The first pitch was awesome, sustained crack climbing with a little bit of everything and I would definitely put at 5.9. I found the initial moves off the ground to be the hardest, with the bulge before the anchors being almost as hard. Currently, there is quite a bit of fixed gear throughout the pitch. Of note, the ledges on this route are significantly smaller than those on Kor Ingalls so if multiple groups are stacking up, you are gonna get really cozy with your new best friends. The 2nd pitch wide portion was actually the hardest moves for me of both routes, but I do very little wide climbing these days. Interestingly, I saw the groups before me yarding on the Star drive bolt protecting this section so maybe it's ok...I bumped a #5 and felt very secure, though gassed. The rest of this pitch is great and maintains consistent climbing of various types (crack, liebacking, chimney). We ended up climbing pitch 3 to the top which didn't result in too much rope drag and my partner and I were able to keep communicating. Rapped down Sacred with a single 70 m (beta in Kor Ingalls post). We had a great time on both routes, though I enjoyed this one slightly more for the more unique, sustained climbing and styles. You can't go wrong with either though, so whichever is open is the one I would hit...or with a little luck, do both like we did! Oct 26, 2023
If you're interested in information about rescue from the Tower and self-rescue / being prepared.  Check out this link. satoriexplore.com/castleton… Feb 29, 2024
